title: 113_hr2936
content: The Act titled "Protecting Immigrants From Legal Exploitation Act of 2013" addresses schemes involving fraudulent immigration services. The Act "Protecting Immigrants From Legal Exploitation Act of 2013" introduces penalties for executing fraudulent immigration schemes, including fines and imprisonment for up to 10 years for those who defraud or obtain money through false representations. It also addresses misrepresentation by individuals falsely claiming to be attorneys or accredited representatives. The Act "Protecting Immigrants From Legal Exploitation Act of 2013" imposes penalties, including fines and imprisonment up to 15 years, for individuals who fraudulently represent themselves in Federal immigration matters. Offenders must also reimburse clients for any fraudulent services provided. The Act "Protecting Immigrants From Legal Exploitation Act of 2013" imposes penalties for fraudulent immigration services. SEC. 3 addresses combating schemes to defraud aliens. The Act "Protecting Immigrants From Legal Exploitation Act of 2013" imposes penalties for fraudulent immigration services, including regulations requiring disclosure of assistance in preparing immigration submissions and signatures from those who received compensation for such services. The Act "Protecting Immigrants From Legal Exploitation Act of 2013" requires individuals providing immigration services to sign a form as a preparer and provide identifying information. The Attorney General can take legal action against fraudulent immigration service providers who misrepresent their legal authority. Definitions for "immigration laws" and "immigration service provider" are provided in this section. An immigration service provider is defined as an individual or entity, excluding attorneys, who offers assistance to aliens for a fee regarding immigration-related filings or proceedings. SEC. 4. RELIEF FOR VICTIMS OF NOTARIO FRAUD. An alien can withdraw an application for immigration status if it was prepared by someone engaged in unauthorized practice of law or immigration fraud. Corrected filings can be resubmitted following a developed procedure by relevant authorities. The Act allows for resubmission of applications or submissions despite filing limitations. An alien can prove departure from the US due to fraudulent advice from unauthorized legal practitioners to waive reentry restrictions. The Attorney General must create regulations within 180 days to implement the contempt authority for immigration judges, allowing civil contempt sanctions, including monetary penalties, for all parties appearing before the judge. SEC. 5. OUTREACH TO IMMIGRANT COMMUNITIES. The Secretary of Homeland Security and the Attorney General will educate aliens on legal service providers to prevent fraud. Information on fraud by unauthorized individuals will be made publicly available at relevant offices. The program authorized by the Secretary of Homeland Security and the Attorney General will provide information to aliens through appropriate offices and websites. Educational materials will be available in various languages, including English and Spanish. Appropriations are authorized for the program. SEC. 6. GRANT PROGRAM TO ASSIST ELIGIBLE APPLICANTS. Establishment of programs to award grants to eligible nonprofit organizations for providing direct legal services to aliens. Eligible nonprofit organizations must have qualified staff with experience in serving immigrants, refugees, and asylum seekers. Grant funds are to be used for programs assisting aliens in removal proceedings and completing applications. Authorization of Appropriations: Sums authorized for carrying out the section, available until expended.
